entry.title: Combined summary - New transaction policies (nVersion=3) for contracting protocols
entry.summary: Bitcoin developers are proposing changes to version 3 (V3) transactions to prevent pinning attacks and improve replace-by-fee (RBF) and child-pays-for-parent (CPFP) protocols. The V3 proposal includes four rules that specify limits on the size and number of "descendant" transactions. Commitment transactions for the Lightning Network should be V3 and have one anchor output. Additionally, a set of mempool/transaction relay policies has been proposed to aid layer-two (L2)/contract protocols, which include additional policy rules applying to V3 transactions and modifications to package RBF rules.Gloria Zhao, a Bitcoin Core developer, has proposed an implementation for Bitcoin Core and provided documentation on GitHub. Feedback and review of the proposal are welcome. The proposal includes additional rules for V3 transactions, which can be replaced even if they do not signal BIP125 replaceability. An unconfirmed V3 transaction cannot have more than one descendant, and any descendant of an unconfirmed V3 transaction must also be V3. Commitment transactions for the Lightning Network should be V3 and have one anchor output. The proposal also includes modifications to package RBF rules, allowing presigned transactions to replace each other and making it possible to use a single anchor output instead of multiple ones. The proposal is aimed at solving Rule 3 pinning and may allow the removal of CPFP carve-out. The proposal has been implemented in Bitcoin Core, and feedback from users is encouraged.Gloria Zhao has proposed a new version of transaction format, V3, aimed at improving replace-by-fee (RBF) and child-pays-for-parent (CPFP) protocols. The proposal aims to prevent pinning attacks where a malicious counterparty prevents a transaction from being replaced by adding many descendant transactions that aren't fee-bumping. The proposal also includes modifications to package RBF rules and suggests allowing OP_TRUE to become a standard script type as part of the policy update to save bytes by having the input be empty of witness data.The proposal for package replace-by-fee (RBF) in Bitcoin transactions aims to improve the security model for layer-two (L2) contracts. It involves using version 3 (V3) transactions that allow for replaceability through child-pays-for-parent (CPFP), which means that only the commitment transaction and up to 1000 virtual bytes (vB) need to be replaced, rather than the entire channel state. Existing standardness rules apply to V3 transactions, and they can replace even if they do not signal BIP125 replaceability.Additionally, Gloria proposes a set of mempool/transaction relay policies to help L2/contract protocols. This proposal incorporates feedback on the PR, and Gloria has written an implementation for Bitcoin Core. The new policies include a set of additional policy rules applying to V3 transactions and modifications to package RBF rules. Feedback and review would be much appreciated.Bitcoin developers are discussing proposed mempool and transaction relay policies to help L2/contract protocols. The update, called BIP-325, adds version 3 transactions (V3) to improve the replace-by-fee (RBF) feature. V3 transactions have a descendant size limit of no more than 1000 virtual bytes to reduce costs for fee-bumping transactions. Commitment transactions in the Lightning Network should be V3 and have one anchor output with a child that is also V3 and at most 1000vB. The proposal involves making OP_TRUE standard and allowing outputs below dust, but there are concerns about utxo set bloat. Additionally, some suggest allowing for a single dust-value output that is immediately spent by the package to make anchors easier to design. The package RBF modifications include adding a new rule that requires all package transactions with mempool conflicts to be V3. There are concerns regarding the pinning attacks possible under the proposal, and the proposal doesn't fix situations where the parent transaction can be "inflated" by tacking on additional inputs.Bastien Teinturier suggests that the main improvement that could be made to the current proposal is restricting the size of the whole V3 package via a specific value in the taproot annex. However, this would make the relay policy stricter, and feedback from users is encouraged. V3 transactions are replaceable even if they don't signal BIP125 replaceability, and V2 transactions can replace V3 transactions and vice versa. Overall, the proposed policies aim to solve Rule 3 pinning and potentially allow for the removal of CPFP carve-out, and feedback from users is welcomed.
